Rehydration either oral or IV fluids is essential.

Persistent

Chronic 
Diarrhoea 
Avoid empirical 
antibiotics 
 
Look for pathogens on stool routine 
microscopy and modified AFB stain (for 
coccidian parasites) and stool culture.  
Administer antimicrobials as per pathogen 
isolated. 
For common etiological agents of Acute Gastroenteritis, see Annexure B.4.2  
Additional information: 
â€¢ 
Danger signs in Acute Gastroenteritis are: 
i. 
Severe dehydration requiring IV fluids 
ii. 
Dysentery (blood in stool): perform stool routine microscopy to rule out Entamoeba 
histiolytica and add metronidazole 400mg TDS (preferably oral) 
iii. 
Elderly with poor oral intake  
iv. 
Immunocompromised condition 
 
 
4.3 Hepatitis Syndrome 
Refer to the National Guidelines on Diagnosis and Management of Viral Hepatitis2
